name: Buenos Aires, 1992-1996
fullDescription:
On August 18, 1996, in the Church of Santa María in Buenos Aires, Father Alejandro Pezet was celebrating Mass when a woman approached him, saying she had found a discarded host on a candle holder at the back of the church.

Father Pezet placed the host in a container of water inside the tabernacle, following the prescribed procedure for handling a soiled host - it should dissolve in the water. When he opened the tabernacle a week later on August 26, he was astonished to find that the host had transformed into a bloody substance.

The Archbishop of Buenos Aires at the time, Jorge Bergoglio (later Pope Francis), ordered that the host be professionally photographed. On September 21, the photographs revealed what appeared to be human flesh and blood.

In 1999, Archbishop Bergoglio authorized a scientific investigation. Dr. Frederic Zugibe, a renowned cardiologist and forensic pathologist from New York, examined the samples without being told their origin. His findings were identical to those of the Lanciano miracle centuries earlier.
historicalContext: This miracle occurred during the pastoral leadership of Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio, who later became Pope Francis. His careful documentation and scientific investigation of this miracle demonstrated the Church's commitment to rigorous examination of claimed miracles. The miracle occurred in the modern era, allowing for extensive photographic documentation and advanced scientific analysis.
scientificEvidence: DNA analysis confirmed the sample is human tissue from a living person.
The tissue is cardiac muscle from the left ventricle of a human heart.
The blood type is AB positive, identical to the Lanciano miracle and the Shroud of Turin.
White blood cells were present, indicating the tissue was from a living heart at the time of analysis.
The tissue shows signs of severe trauma and inflammation, consistent with torture.

Dr. Zugibe stated: 'The analyzed material is a fragment of the heart muscle found in the wall of the left ventricle close to the valves. This muscle is responsible for the contraction of the heart. It should be borne in mind that the left cardiac ventricle pumps blood to all parts of the body. The heart muscle is in an inflammatory condition and contains a large number of white blood cells. This indicates that the heart was alive at the time the sample was taken.'
When Dr. Zugibe was told the sample was from a consecrated host that had been kept in water for a month and then photographed, he was stunned and stated this was scientifically inexplicable.

witnessTestimonies.name: Father Alejandro Pezet
witnessTestimonies.role: Parish Priest, Santa María Church, Buenos Aires
witnessTestimonies.testimony: When I opened the tabernacle a week after placing the host in water, I saw that it had not dissolved. Instead, it had transformed into what appeared to be bloody tissue. I immediately informed the Archbishop, and we began documenting everything carefully.

witnessTestimonies.name: Dr. Frederic Zugibe
witnessTestimonies.role: Chief Medical Examiner, Rockland County, New York; Cardiologist and Forensic Pathologist
witnessTestimonies.testimony: The analyzed material is a fragment of heart muscle. What is most impressive is that this tissue is from a living heart. How can this be explained? Only if the heart was alive at the time the sample was taken. It is my contention that the heart was alive since the white blood cells require a living organism to sustain them.

witnessTestimonies.name: Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio (Pope Francis)
witnessTestimonies.testimony: I ordered that the host be photographed and that samples be taken for scientific analysis. The results confirmed what we witnessed - this is a miracle that calls us to deeper faith in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.

timeline.event: A parishioner finds a discarded host. Father Pezet places it in water in the tabernacle.
Father Pezet opens the tabernacle and finds the host has transformed into bloody tissue.
Professional photographs are taken, clearly showing flesh and blood.
Dr. Ricardo Castañón Gomez takes samples for scientific analysis.
Samples are analyzed by Dr. Frederic Zugibe in New York. He confirms it is living cardiac tissue.
Further DNA analysis is conducted, confirming the tissue is human and from a living person.
The miraculous host is preserved and venerated at Santa María Church in Buenos Aires.

churchInfo.name: Church of Santa María
churchInfo.address: Av. Paseo Colón 415, C1063ACD Buenos Aires, Argentina

name: Brussels, 1370
fullDescription:
In 1369, a wealthy merchant from Enghien who harbored intense hatred for the Catholic religion conspired to desecrate the Blessed Sacrament. He worked with a young accomplice from Louvain to have consecrated Hosts stolen from a church. However, divine justice moved swiftly - the merchant was mysteriously assassinated just days after the theft, before he could carry out his sacrilegious plans.

After her husband's death, his widow came into possession of the stolen Hosts. Not understanding their sacred nature or perhaps sharing her late husband's antipathy toward the Church, she sold or gave the consecrated Hosts to members of the Jewish community in Brussels.

On Good Friday, 1370 - the very day Christians commemorate Christ's crucifixion and death - a group gathered in the synagogue in Brussels with the stolen Hosts. In a deliberate act of desecration mirroring the Passion of Christ, they began to stab the Hosts with daggers and knives, attempting to destroy them.

As the blades struck the Hosts, an extraordinary miracle occurred before the eyes of all present. Blood began to pour forth from the Hosts - real, flowing blood that came from the particles of bread being stabbed. The Hosts bled profusely, as if they were living flesh being wounded. The desecrators were terrified and horrified by what they had witnessed.

Panicked by the miracle and fearing the consequences of their actions, those who had stabbed the Hosts hastily gave them to a respected Catholic merchant, hoping to rid themselves of the evidence. This merchant, recognizing the sacred nature of what had occurred, initially attempted to secretly transport the Hosts to the Jewish community in Cologne, Germany, paying a female Jewish convert to Christianity to deliver them.

However, the woman's conscience tormented her. Overwhelmed with remorse for participating in the concealment of such a grave sacrilege, she went to the parson of Notre-Dame de la Chapelle in Brussels and revealed the entire story. The priest immediately took possession of the miraculous bleeding Hosts.

When Duke of Brabant learned of the desecration and the miracle, he ordered a full investigation. Based on the testimony of the repentant woman and other witnesses, he commanded that those who had stabbed the Hosts be executed by burning at the stake. The remaining members of the Jewish community in Brussels were banished from the city, and their property was confiscated.

The miraculous bleeding Hosts were placed in precious reliquaries and solemnly enshrined in the Collegiate Church of Saint Gudula (now the Cathedral of St. Michael and St. Gudula), the principal church of Brussels. Saint Gudula is the patron saint of Brussels, and the church became the cathedral of the archdiocese.
historicalContext: This miracle occurred during a period of significant religious and social tension in medieval Europe. The 14th century saw periodic outbreaks of violence against Jewish communities, often sparked by accusations of Host desecration. While the historical context of Jewish-Christian relations during this period was complex and tragic, the miracle itself became an important part of Brussels' religious identity. Emperor Charles V and the Habsburg dynasty, recognizing the miracle's significance, donated seven magnificent stained glass windows depicting the miracle to the cathedral. The miracle became deeply woven into the civic and religious life of Brussels and is considered something of a national symbol of Belgium.
scientificEvidence: Multiple witnesses testified to seeing the Hosts bleed when stabbed with daggers and knives.
The bleeding was described as real, flowing blood coming from the wounded Hosts - not a discoloration or stain, but actual blood.
The testimony of the remorseful female convert was considered credible enough by Duke of Brabant to order executions and banishment based upon it.
The miraculous Hosts were examined by Church authorities and deemed authentic before being enshrined in reliquaries.
Emperor Charles V and the Habsburg family's donation of seven stained glass windows depicting the miracle demonstrates the high-level recognition and authentication of the event.
The Hosts were preserved in the cathedral for centuries and became central to Brussels' religious identity.

witnessTestimonies.name: Those Present in the Synagogue
witnessTestimonies.testimony: When we stabbed the Hosts with our daggers, blood began pouring from them as if they were living flesh. We were filled with terror at what we had done and what we had witnessed.

witnessTestimonies.name: The Female Jewish Convert
witnessTestimonies.role: Woman paid to transport the Hosts
witnessTestimonies.testimony: I was given money to take the bleeding Hosts to Cologne, but my conscience would not allow me to continue in this deception. I went to the parson of Notre-Dame de la Chapelle and confessed everything - how the Hosts were stolen, how they were stabbed and bled, and the plot to hide them. I could no longer bear the weight of this terrible secret.

witnessTestimonies.name: Parson of Notre-Dame de la Chapelle
witnessTestimonies.role: Priest who received the miraculous Hosts
witnessTestimonies.testimony: A woman came to me with a confession that filled me with both horror and awe. She told me of Hosts that had been stolen and desecrated - stabbed with knives until they bled. She brought them to me, and I could see they were indeed sacred. I immediately reported this to the ecclesiastical and civil authorities and took the Hosts into protective custody.

witnessTestimonies.name: Duke of Brabant
witnessTestimonies.testimony: Based on the credible testimony of witnesses, including the woman who came forward in repentance, I have ordered justice to be done. Those who perpetrated this horrible sacrilege against the Body of Christ shall be punished according to the law. The bleeding Hosts shall be enshrined with honor in our principal church as a witness to the Real Presence.

witnessTestimonies.name: Emperor Charles V
witnessTestimonies.role: Holy Roman Emperor and patron of the shrine
witnessTestimonies.testimony: The miracle of the bleeding Hosts of Brussels is a treasure of our realm and a powerful witness to the Catholic Faith. I and my family donate these seven stained glass windows to the Cathedral of Saint Gudula so that future generations may remember this divine intervention and be strengthened in their belief in the Real Presence of Christ in the Holy Eucharist.

timeline.event: A wealthy merchant from Enghien arranges to have consecrated Hosts stolen, working with an accomplice from Louvain.
The merchant is mysteriously assassinated just days after the theft, before he can carry out his plans for the Hosts.
The merchant's widow gives or sells the stolen Hosts to members of the Jewish community in Brussels.
In the synagogue in Brussels, the Hosts are stabbed with daggers and knives. They begin bleeding profusely - real blood flowing from the wounded Hosts.
Terrified by the miracle, the desecrators give the bleeding Hosts to a Catholic merchant.

A female Jewish convert to Christianity, who was paid to transport the Hosts to Cologne, instead confesses to the parson of Notre-Dame de la Chapelle. The priest takes possession of the miraculous Hosts.
Duke of Brabant investigates. Based on witness testimony, he orders those who stabbed the Hosts to be burned at the stake and banishes the remaining Jews from Brussels, confiscating their property.
The miraculous bleeding Hosts are placed in reliquaries and enshrined in the Collegiate Church of Saint Gudula in Brussels.
Emperor Charles V and the Habsburg family donate seven magnificent stained glass windows depicting the miracle to the cathedral.
The miracle becomes central to Brussels' religious identity and an annual procession on the feast of Saint Gudula commemorates the event.
The Cathedral of St. Michael and St. Gudula in Brussels preserves the memory of this miracle through the Habsburg stained glass windows and the cathedral's history.

name: Tumaco, 1906
fullDescription:
On the morning of January 31, 1906, a catastrophic undersea earthquake struck off the coast of Ecuador and Colombia. The earthquake, estimated between magnitude 8.3 and 8.8, was one of the most powerful seismic events of the 20th century. The ground in the coastal town of Tumaco, Colombia, shook violently for nearly ten minutes, causing widespread panic among the population.

As the terrifying tremors continued, the frightened inhabitants of Tumaco witnessed an even more ominous sight - the sea suddenly began to retreat from the shore. The ocean pulled back approximately one kilometer, exposing the seabed and leaving boats stranded on dry land. The people of Tumaco knew what this meant: a massive tsunami was forming and would soon crash upon their defenseless town with devastating force.

In their terror, the townspeople ran to their parish church and begged their pastor, Augustinian Recollect priest Fray Gerardo Larrondo de San José, to intercede for their protection. Father Larrondo, understanding the grave danger, immediately retrieved the Blessed Sacrament from the tabernacle and called the entire community to follow him in procession.

Carrying the monstrance containing the Sacred Host high above his head, Father Larrondo led the entire population of Tumaco toward the beach. As they processed, they could see on the horizon an enormous wall of water advancing toward the town with terrifying speed. Scientific studies would later confirm that the tsunami reached heights of up to 5 meters (16 feet) in the Tumaco area.

When they reached the water's edge, Father Larrondo walked forward alone, holding the monstrance aloft. Standing before the advancing tsunami, he raised the Blessed Sacrament as high as he could reach and traced a large sign of the cross over the threatening waters. Crying out for divine mercy and protection, he blessed the massive wave in the name of Jesus Christ, truly present in the Eucharist.

According to numerous eyewitnesses, an extraordinary miracle occurred at that moment. The enormous wall of water - which was racing toward Tumaco with unstoppable force - suddenly appeared to hesitate. The wave seemed to pause in its advance, as if hitting an invisible barrier. Then, against all natural laws, it began to recede. The tsunami that should have destroyed Tumaco turned back into the ocean and dissipated, leaving the town completely unharmed.

The contrast with neighboring communities was stark and sobering. Along the same coastline of Ecuador and Colombia, other towns and villages were devastated by the same tsunami. Scientific records and historical accounts estimate that between 500 and 1,500 people died in coastal communities struck by the wave. But Tumaco, blessed by the Eucharist, suffered no deaths and virtually no damage.

The people of Tumaco, overwhelmed with gratitude and awe, returned in solemn procession to their church. Father Larrondo solemnly enthroned the Blessed Sacrament on the altar, and the entire town knelt in thanksgiving for their miraculous deliverance. From that day forward, January 31st has been commemorated annually in Tumaco with special processions, Eucharistic adoration, and acts of thanksgiving for the miracle that saved their town.
historicalContext: This miracle occurred during a period of significant seismic activity along the Pacific coast of South America. The 1906 Ecuador-Colombia earthquake was one of the most powerful earthquakes ever recorded in the region, generating a devastating tsunami that affected hundreds of kilometers of coastline. In an era when tsunami warning systems did not exist, coastal populations had no way to protect themselves except prayer. The miracle of Tumaco stands as a powerful testament to God's intervention through the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist, demonstrating that faith can move not only mountains but also the very seas themselves.
scientificEvidence: The 1906 Ecuador-Colombia earthquake is well-documented in scientific literature, with estimates of magnitude 8.3-8.8.
Seismological records confirm the earthquake generated a massive tsunami that struck the Pacific coast.
Scientific studies document that the tsunami reached heights of up to 5 meters (16 feet) in the Tumaco area.
Historical records show that 500 to 1,500 people died from the same tsunami in other coastal communities along Ecuador and Colombia.
Tumaco, despite being directly in the path of the tsunami and having the same vulnerability as other coastal towns, suffered no deaths and minimal damage.
The numerous eyewitnesses to the miracle included the entire population of Tumaco, who all witnessed the wave stopping and receding after Father Larrondo blessed it with the Eucharist.
The miracle has been commemorated annually for over 120 years, indicating the profound impact it had on the community and the reliability of the witness testimony.

The contrast between Tumaco's preservation and the devastation of neighboring towns cannot be explained by natural geographical features or protective structures - Tumaco had the same exposure to the tsunami as other affected communities.

witnessTestimonies.name: Fray Gerardo Larrondo de San José
witnessTestimonies.role: Augustinian Recollect Priest, Pastor of Tumaco
witnessTestimonies.testimony: When the earthquake struck and the sea retreated, I knew a terrible tsunami was coming. The people came to the church in terror, begging for help. I took the Blessed Sacrament and led them to the beach. When I saw the enormous wave approaching, I raised the monstrance and made the sign of the cross over the waters, crying out to Jesus in the Eucharist for mercy. Before our eyes, the wave stopped its advance and turned back into the sea. Our Lord in the Blessed Sacrament saved us all.

witnessTestimonies.name: Townspeople of Tumaco
witnessTestimonies.testimony: We all saw it with our own eyes - the entire town was there. The wall of water was racing toward us, and we knew we were about to die. But when Father Larrondo blessed the wave with the Blessed Sacrament, it stopped. It actually stopped and turned back. The other towns along the coast were destroyed, but we were saved. It was not a natural phenomenon - it was a miracle from God through the Holy Eucharist.

witnessTestimonies.name: Survivors from neighboring towns
witnessTestimonies.role: Witnesses to the tsunami's devastation elsewhere
witnessTestimonies.testimony: The same tsunami that killed hundreds in our communities did not touch Tumaco. We heard the accounts of what happened there - how their priest blessed the waters with the Eucharist and the wave turned back. We lost so many people, but Tumaco lost no one. There is no natural explanation for this. It was a miracle.

timeline.event: A massive undersea earthquake (magnitude 8.3-8.8) strikes off the coast of Ecuador and Colombia. The ground shakes violently in Tumaco for nearly ten minutes.
The sea retreats approximately one kilometer from the shore - a warning sign of an approaching tsunami.
Terrified townspeople run to the church and beg Father Larrondo for help. He retrieves the Blessed Sacrament and leads the entire community in procession to the beach.
An enormous wave, 5 meters (16 feet) high, advances toward Tumaco. Father Larrondo raises the monstrance and blesses the waters with the sign of the cross.
Miracle: The tsunami stops its advance, appears to hit an invisible barrier, then recedes back into the ocean. Tumaco is completely spared.
The same tsunami devastates other coastal communities in Ecuador and Colombia, killing an estimated 500-1,500 people.
The people of Tumaco return in procession to the church. Father Larrondo solemnly enthrones the Blessed Sacrament on the altar in thanksgiving.
January 31st is commemorated annually in Tumaco with processions, Eucharistic adoration, and acts of thanksgiving for the miracle.
Tumaco celebrates the 120th anniversary of the Eucharistic miracle that stopped the tsunami, continuing the tradition of annual thanksgiving.

churchInfo.name: Parish Church of Tumaco (dedicated to the miracle)

name: Ludbreg, 1411
fullDescription:
In 1411, during Mass at the church in Ludbreg, Croatia, a priest was celebrating the Holy Sacrifice while struggling with doubts about whether the Body and Blood of Christ were really present in the Eucharistic species. As he pronounced the words of consecration over the wine, he was filled with uncertainty about the Church's teaching on transubstantiation.

At the precise moment after he finished the words of consecration, the wine in the chalice miraculously transformed into visible Blood - real, red, human blood. The priest was overwhelmed with fear and confusion at what he had witnessed. Instead of revealing the miracle to the faithful or Church authorities, he made a decision that would keep this miracle hidden for many years.

The doubting priest, perhaps out of shame for his lack of faith or fear of the consequences, decided to conceal the miraculous Blood. He hired a trusted workman to embed the sacred relic in the wall behind the main altar, creating a secret hiding place. The priest swore the workman to absolute silence about what they had done, and the miracle remained completely hidden from everyone.

The priest kept this extraordinary secret throughout his entire life. Only at the hour of his death, when his conscience finally compelled him to reveal the truth, did he confess what had happened during that Mass decades earlier. He told of his doubt, the miraculous transformation of the wine into visible Blood, and where he had hidden it in the wall behind the altar.

Church authorities immediately investigated and found the hidden relic exactly where the dying priest described. The Blood was still perfectly preserved, unchanged despite the many years it had been sealed in the wall. The miracle was authenticated, and the precious Blood was removed from its hiding place and enshrined properly for veneration.

The fame of the miracle spread throughout Europe. On April 14, 1513, Pope Leo X published a papal Bull officially recognizing the miracle and granting special permissions for its veneration. Pope Leo X himself carried the sacred relic several times in solemn procession through the streets of Rome before it was returned to Croatia with great honor.
historicalContext: This miracle occurred in medieval Croatia during a period when doubts about the Real Presence were not uncommon, even among clergy. The priest's decision to hide the miracle for decades, only revealing it on his deathbed, adds a unique and poignant dimension to this story. The miracle's eventual discovery and authentication, followed by Pope Leo X's personal veneration of the relic in Rome, demonstrates the Church's commitment to honoring authentic Eucharistic miracles while maintaining rigorous standards of investigation.
scientificEvidence: The wine transformed into visible, recognizable Blood immediately after the words of consecration - witnessed directly by the celebrating priest.
The Blood remained perfectly preserved for decades while hidden in the wall, without any form of artificial preservation.
When discovered after the priest's deathbed confession, the Blood was found to be intact and uncorrupted despite the passage of many years.
The Blood has remained perfectly preserved for over 600 years and shows no signs of decay or deterioration.
In 1721, a precious monstrance was commissioned by Countess Eleonora Batthyany-Strattman to house the relic, and the Blood remains visible within it to this day.
Pope Leo X personally examined and authenticated the relic in Rome before authorizing its return to Croatia.

witnessTestimonies.name: The Doubting Priest
witnessTestimonies.testimony: I am ashamed to confess that during Mass, I doubted the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist. But the moment I finished the words of consecration over the wine, it transformed before my eyes into real Blood. I was terrified and, in my weakness, I hid the miracle in the wall rather than revealing it. Now, as I lie dying, I must confess this secret I have carried for so many years. The Blood is hidden behind the main altar. May God forgive my lack of faith and my cowardice in concealing His miraculous sign.

witnessTestimonies.name: The Workman
witnessTestimonies.role: Artisan who helped hide the Blood
witnessTestimonies.testimony: The priest came to me in secrecy and asked me to help him embed something sacred in the wall behind the altar. He swore me to silence, and I kept that vow faithfully. Now that he has revealed the truth from his deathbed, I can confirm: we placed the vessel containing the miraculous Blood exactly where he said. I have carried this secret for decades.

witnessTestimonies.name: Church Authorities
witnessTestimonies.testimony: Following the dying priest's confession, we immediately investigated the wall behind the main altar. We found the hidden relic exactly as he described. The Blood was perfectly preserved, showing no signs of corruption despite being sealed away for decades. This is clearly a miraculous preservation. We have removed it from its hiding place and will properly enshrine it for the veneration of the faithful.

witnessTestimonies.name: Pope Leo X
witnessTestimonies.testimony: Having thoroughly examined the miraculous Blood of Ludbreg and verified its authenticity, I issue this Papal Bull on April 14, 1513, granting permission for its public veneration. I myself have carried this sacred relic in solemn procession through the streets of Rome, and I can attest to its power to inspire faith and devotion. This miracle is a precious gift to the Church, confirming the Real Presence of Christ in the Most Holy Eucharist.

witnessTestimonies.name: Countess Eleonora Batthyany-Strattman
witnessTestimonies.testimony: Moved by devotion to the Precious Blood of Our Lord preserved in this miracle, I have commissioned a magnificent monstrance to properly house and display this sacred treasure for the veneration of pilgrims. May all who gaze upon this miraculous Blood be strengthened in their faith in the Real Presence.

timeline.event: During Mass at Ludbreg, a priest doubts the Real Presence. Immediately after consecration, the wine transforms into visible Blood.
The frightened priest decides to hide the miracle. He has a workman embed the Blood in the wall behind the main altar and swears him to secrecy.
After carrying the secret for many years, the priest finally confesses the miracle on his deathbed, revealing where the Blood is hidden.
Church authorities investigate and find the hidden Blood perfectly preserved in the wall. The miracle is authenticated and the Blood is properly enshrined.
The miraculous Blood is brought to Rome for examination.
Pope Leo X publishes a Papal Bull officially recognizing the miracle and granting special permissions for veneration. He personally carries the relic in procession through Rome.
The miraculous Blood is returned to Croatia with great honor and enshrined in Ludbreg.
Countess Eleonora Batthyany-Strattman commissions a precious monstrance to house the miraculous Blood.
During a session in Varaždin, local authorities vow to build a chapel at Ludbreg in honor of the miracle if a plague epidemic ends. The plague is miraculously averted.
After democracy is restored in Croatia following the fall of communism, the vow made in 1739 is finally fulfilled, and the promised chapel is completed.

timeline.date: Present Day (First week of September annually)
timeline.event: The Eucharistic miracle is celebrated with special solemnities. Thousands of pilgrims visit Ludbreg each year to venerate the Precious Blood, which remains perfectly preserved after more than 600 years.

name: Bordeaux, 1822
fullDescription:
On Septuagesima Sunday, February 3, 1822, a profound Eucharistic miracle took place in the chapel of the Association of the Holy Family in Bordeaux, France. The chapel belonged to a religious community that had been founded just twenty months earlier, in 1820, by the Venerable Father Pierre Noaille. The community was dedicated to prayer and service, with special devotion to the Blessed Sacrament.

On that Sunday, Father Pierre Noaille, the founder, was unable to celebrate Mass himself due to illness. He asked Abbot Pierre-Justin Delort to substitute for him in the liturgical celebrations. After Mass concluded, Abbot Delort gave the final benediction with the Blessed Sacrament, holding the monstrance high for the congregation to adore the exposed Host.

Immediately after the benediction, Jesus Christ Himself appeared visibly in the Host, which was still exposed for public adoration. The vision was clear and detailed - Jesus appeared giving a blessing to the faithful gathered in the chapel. The miraculous appearance lasted for more than twenty minutes, during which many people in the congregation witnessed the sacred vision.

Abbot Delort himself later wrote a detailed description of what he saw: 'I saw our Saviour, head, chest, and arms, in the middle of the circle that served Him as a frame like a painting. He was dressed with a dark red scarf draped over His shoulder and chest.' Overcome with awe and wanting confirmation that he was not experiencing a personal hallucination, Abbot Delort called over the altar server to look at the Host. The server immediately confirmed that he, too, could see Jesus clearly in the exposed Host.

As word of the miracle spread throughout the chapel, more and more faithful confirmed they could see the vision. One witness testified to hearing Jesus speak the divine words: 'I Am He Who Is' - echoing God's self-revelation to Moses from the burning bush (Exodus 3:14), affirming His eternal and divine nature.

The miracle occurred in the church of St. Eulalia on Rue Mazarin in Bordeaux, where the Community of the Holy Family had established themselves. News of the miracle spread rapidly throughout Bordeaux and beyond, bringing thousands of pilgrims to the chapel.
historicalContext: This miracle occurred in post-Revolutionary France, during a period of religious renewal after the devastating persecution of the Church during the French Revolution and Napoleonic era. The early 19th century saw a resurgence of Catholic faith and new religious communities being founded. The Holy Family community, founded by Father Noaille in 1820, was part of this renewal. The miracle happened just twenty months after the community's foundation, as if God was placing His seal of approval on their mission and devotion to the Eucharist.
scientificEvidence: The vision of Christ in the Host was witnessed by multiple people simultaneously for over 20 minutes, ruling out individual hallucination.
Abbot Delort, who had not expected or sought such a vision, independently called the altar server to verify what he was seeing - the server confirmed the same vision without prompting.
Multiple witnesses in the congregation testified to seeing the same image of Jesus Christ in the Host.
At least one witness reported hearing the words 'I Am He Who Is' spoken by Christ during the vision.
The detailed description provided by Abbot Delort - showing Christ's head, chest, and arms, dressed in a dark red scarf - was consistent across multiple witnesses.
The monstrance used during the miracle has been preserved as a precious relic and can still be venerated today.
Archbishop d'Aviau of Bordeaux conducted a thorough ecclesiastical investigation, personally hearing witness testimonies before officially approving the miracle.

witnessTestimonies.name: Abbot Pierre-Justin Delort
witnessTestimonies.role: Celebrating Priest who gave the Benediction
witnessTestimonies.testimony: Immediately after I gave the benediction with the Blessed Sacrament, I saw an extraordinary vision in the Host. I saw our Saviour - His head, chest, and arms - in the middle of the circle of the Host as if it were a frame like a painting. He was dressed with a dark red scarf draped over His shoulder and chest. He appeared to be giving a blessing. I could hardly believe what I was seeing, so I called the altar server to confirm, and he too saw Our Lord in the Host. This vision lasted more than twenty minutes.

witnessTestimonies.name: The Altar Server
witnessTestimonies.testimony: When Father Delort called me over to look at the Host in the monstrance, I immediately saw Jesus Christ clearly visible - His face, chest, and arms, exactly as Father Delort described. I had never seen anything like it in my life. It was not my imagination - He was truly there, blessing us from the Host.

witnessTestimonies.name: Witness in the Congregation
witnessTestimonies.testimony: I heard the voice of Jesus saying 'I Am He Who Is' during the vision. It was unmistakable - the voice of God Himself, declaring His eternal nature. Many of us in the chapel saw Him in the Host, blessing us for more than twenty minutes.

witnessTestimonies.name: Venerable Father Pierre Noaille
witnessTestimonies.role: Founder of the Community of the Holy Family
witnessTestimonies.testimony: Though I was ill and could not celebrate Mass that day, I thank God that He chose to manifest Himself in such a powerful way in our humble chapel. This miracle confirms the importance of devotion to the Most Holy Eucharist, which is the heart of our community's charism.

witnessTestimonies.name: Archbishop D'Aviau
witnessTestimonies.testimony: After personally hearing the testimonies of the faithful who witnessed this marvel, and after thorough investigation, I officially approve this Eucharistic miracle. The witnesses are credible, their accounts are consistent, and the event clearly demonstrates the Real Presence of Our Lord Jesus Christ in the Blessed Sacrament.

timeline.event: Venerable Father Pierre Noaille founds the Community of the Holy Family in Bordeaux.
The community establishes itself in the Church of St. Eulalia on Rue Mazarin, Bordeaux, with special devotion to the Eucharist.
Father Noaille is ill. Abbot Pierre-Justin Delort celebrates Mass in his place.
After Mass, Abbot Delort gives Benediction with the Blessed Sacrament. Immediately afterward, Jesus Christ appears visibly in the exposed Host.
The vision lasts more than 20 minutes. Abbot Delort calls the altar server to verify the vision. Multiple members of the congregation witness Christ in the Host.
At least one witness hears Jesus speak the words: 'I Am He Who Is.'
Archbishop d'Aviau of Bordeaux conducts an ecclesiastical investigation, personally hearing witness testimonies.
The Archbishop officially approves the miracle. The chapel becomes known as the 'Chapel of the Miracle.'
The monstrance used during the miracle is preserved as a precious relic.
The miraculous monstrance is kept in Martillac, France, in the church of the contemplative community 'La Solitude,' where pilgrims can venerate this precious relic of the Eucharistic miracle.

churchInfo.name: La Solitude (Contemplative Community) - Location of the miraculous monstrance
churchInfo.visitingHours: Contact the community for visiting hours and access to the Chapel of the Miracle

name: Faverney, 1608
fullDescription:
In the early 17th century, Protestantism and Calvinism were spreading rapidly through France, creating religious uncertainty even within monasteries. In the city of Faverney stood a Benedictine Abbey whose monks had departed significantly from the strict rule of their founder, St. Benedict. However, they maintained fervent devotion to Our Lady under the title of Notre-Dame la Blanche (Our Lady of the White), known throughout the region for miracles attributed to her intercession.

On the Vigil of Pentecost in 1608, the monks decided to prepare a special altar for the exposition and adoration of the Blessed Sacrament for the feast. Because the lunette of the monstrance was unusually large, they decided to place two consecrated Hosts inside it for adoration. When Vespers concluded that evening, the monks left the monstrance exposed on the temporary wooden altar and retired to their cells.

During the night, a devastating fire broke out in the church. The flames consumed the temporary altar, reducing it completely to ashes, along with all the sacred furnishings, candles, and decorations surrounding it. The next morning, the sacristan opened the church doors and was met with a church full of smoke and the provisional altar completely destroyed by fire.

As the sacristan and monks began to survey the damage and extinguish the remaining embers, a 15-year-old novice named Hudelot noticed something absolutely extraordinary. The monstrance containing the two consecrated Hosts was suspended in mid-air, without any visible support! It was hovering several feet above where the altar had stood, tilted at an angle toward - but not touching - the iron grille that had been at the back of the now-destroyed altar. The monstrance was completely untouched by the fire that had destroyed everything around it.

Word spread rapidly throughout Faverney and the surrounding regions. Within hours, the church was filled with villagers, priests from neighboring parishes, and Capuchin monks from the nearby city of Vesoul, all coming to witness the spectacle. Among the Eucharistic miracles in history, few have been witnessed by so many people for so long - the monstrance remained suspended in mid-air for an entire day and a half, with hundreds of continuous witnesses.

Throughout Monday and into Tuesday, priests took turns celebrating Mass in an unbroken sequence while the miracle continued before their eyes. On Tuesday morning at 10:00 AM, during the consecration of one of these Masses, the entire congregation witnessed the monstrance slowly shift from its tilted position to become perfectly vertical, and then gradually descend to rest on the new altar that had been brought into the church. The miracle had lasted approximately 33 hours.

The ecclesiastical authorities conducted a thorough canonical investigation. Reports from fifty-three of the most important witnesses - including several Protestant converts who had witnessed the miracle and subsequently converted to Catholicism - were recorded in writing and submitted to Rome.
historicalContext: This miracle occurred during a critical period of religious conflict in France. The Protestant Reformation had created deep divisions, and many Catholics were wavering in their faith, particularly regarding belief in the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist. The dramatic and public nature of this miracle - witnessed by hundreds of people for 33 hours - provided powerful evidence for the Real Presence at exactly the time when it was most needed. Several Protestant witnesses converted to Catholicism after witnessing the miracle, demonstrating its evangelistic impact.
scientificEvidence: The monstrance, made of metal and containing glass, hovered unsupported in mid-air for approximately 33 hours, defying the law of gravity.
The monstrance was completely untouched by fire that had consumed everything surrounding it - the wooden altar, candles, decorations, and sacred furnishings were reduced to ashes.
The suspension was witnessed continuously by hundreds of people, including clergy, religious, and laypeople from multiple towns and cities.
Fifty-three formal witness testimonies were recorded in writing during the canonical investigation, providing extensive documentation.
Several Protestant witnesses who came as skeptics converted to Catholicism after witnessing the miracle, attesting to its authenticity.
The monstrance shifted position and descended at the precise moment of consecration during Mass, showing intelligent, purposeful movement rather than random floating.
The Archbishop of Besançon conducted a thorough investigation and declared the miracle authentic on July 10, 1608.
Pope Paul V reviewed the evidence and granted a Bull of Indulgence on September 13, 1608, giving papal approval to the miracle.

witnessTestimonies.name: Novice Hudelot
witnessTestimonies.testimony: When I entered the church the morning after the fire and saw the monstrance floating in the air where the altar had been destroyed, I could hardly believe my eyes. I called out to the other monks, and soon hundreds came to witness this wonder. I watched it hover there for a full day and a half - it was the most extraordinary sight I have ever seen, and it has strengthened my faith beyond measure.

witnessTestimonies.name: Sacristan of Faverney Abbey
witnessTestimonies.testimony: I opened the church that morning to find it filled with smoke. The provisional altar was completely destroyed by fire - reduced to nothing but ashes. Everything on and around the altar had been consumed. But there, suspended in the air several feet above where the altar had stood, was the monstrance with the Blessed Sacrament, completely unharmed and glowing with divine presence.

witnessTestimonies.name: Capuchin Monks of Vesoul
witnessTestimonies.testimony: When we heard reports of the miracle, we hurried to Faverney immediately. We witnessed the monstrance hovering without support for many hours. We celebrated Mass continuously while the miracle persisted, and at the moment of consecration on Tuesday morning, we all saw the monstrance shift to vertical position and slowly descend to the new altar. This is undeniably a work of God.

witnessTestimonies.name: Protestant Witnesses
witnessTestimonies.testimony: We came as skeptics, not believing in the Catholic teaching of the Real Presence. But seeing the monstrance suspended in mid-air for an entire day and a half, witnessed by hundreds of us simultaneously, we could no longer deny the truth. If Christ is not truly present in the Eucharist, how could this miracle occur? We have renounced our errors and embraced the Catholic Faith.

witnessTestimonies.name: Archbishop of Besançon
witnessTestimonies.testimony: After conducting a thorough canonical investigation and examining the testimonies of fifty-three reliable witnesses, I solemnly declare that this is an authentic Eucharistic miracle. On July 10, 1608, I officially recognize this miraculous event as a divine intervention confirming the Real Presence of Our Lord Jesus Christ in the Most Holy Eucharist.

witnessTestimonies.name: Pope Paul V
witnessTestimonies.testimony: Having received the report from the Archbishop of Rodi, our Nuncio in Brussels, concerning the thorough investigation of the Eucharistic miracle at Faverney, and having examined the abundant testimonial evidence, I grant a Bull of Indulgence to all who venerate this miracle and visit the shrine, thereby giving our apostolic approval to its authenticity.

timeline.event: The Benedictine monks prepare a special altar for Eucharistic adoration. Two Hosts are placed in a large monstrance and left exposed after Vespers.
A fire breaks out in the church, completely destroying the temporary altar and all furnishings, reducing everything to ashes.
The sacristan opens the church to find it full of smoke and the altar destroyed. 15-year-old novice Hudelot discovers the monstrance floating in mid-air, untouched by the fire.
News spreads rapidly. Hundreds of people - villagers, priests, and religious - flood the church to witness the miracle. The monstrance remains suspended throughout the day.
The miracle continues. Priests celebrate Masses in continuous sequence while the monstrance hovers. The crowd of witnesses grows.

At the moment of consecration during Mass, the entire congregation witnesses the monstrance shift to vertical position and slowly descend to rest on the new altar. The miracle has lasted approximately 33 hours.
The Archbishop of Besançon conducts canonical investigation. Fifty-three formal witness testimonies are recorded in writing, including several from Protestant converts.
The Archbishop of Besançon officially declares the miracle authentic.
Pope Paul V, after reviewing the evidence, grants a Bull of Indulgence, giving papal approval to the miracle.
One of the two miraculous Hosts is given to the town of Dôle. Both Hosts are preserved and venerated.
The Host that was given to Dôle is desecrated and destroyed by anti-religious revolutionaries.
The surviving miraculous Host continues to be preserved and venerated in Faverney, drawing pilgrims from around the world to this powerful witness of the Real Presence.

churchInfo.name: Abbey Church of Faverney

name: Paris, 1290
fullDescription:
On Easter Sunday, April 2, 1290, a man named Jonathas, who hated the Catholic Faith and did not believe in the Real Presence of Christ in the Holy Eucharist, managed to gain possession of a consecrated Host. Filled with contempt and rage against the Blessed Sacrament, he was determined to prove that the Church's teaching about the Eucharist was false.

Jonathas took the Host to his home and began to desecrate it in increasingly violent ways. He first stabbed the Host with a knife, and immediately blood began to flow from it. The blood poured out so profusely that it filled the container in which he had placed the Host. Panic-stricken by what he had witnessed, but still hardened in his unbelief, Jonathas decided to destroy the evidence by throwing the Host into a fire.

When he cast the Blessed Sacrament into the flames, instead of burning, the Host miraculously arose from the fire and hovered in the air, untouched by the flames. Terrified but still obstinate, Jonathas then threw the Host into a pot of boiling water, hoping the extreme heat would finally destroy it.

To his utter amazement, the Host arose from the boiling water and once again began hovering in mid-air. As Jonathas and others watched in awe and terror, the Host transformed before their eyes, taking the visible form of a crucifix - showing Christ crucified. This powerful manifestation of Christ's Real Presence and His suffering finally broke through Jonathas's hardened heart.

Filled with remorse and fear, Jonathas finally deposited the miraculous Host in the bowl of a parishioner of the Church of Saint-Jean-en-Grève, who immediately brought the Blessed Sacrament to her parish priest. The priest reverently received the Host and reported the miracle to Church authorities.
historicalContext: This miracle occurred in medieval Paris during the reign of King Philip IV (Philip the Fair), a time when anti-Catholic sentiment and sacrilege against the Eucharist were not uncommon. The dramatic nature of the miracle - with the Host bleeding, surviving fire and boiling water, and transforming into a crucifix - made it one of the most widely known Eucharistic miracles of the Middle Ages. The story was documented by Archbishop Rupp in his 'History of the Church of Paris' in the section on Bishop Simon Matifas of Busay, who held the See of St. Denis from 1290 to 1304.
scientificEvidence: The Host bled profusely when stabbed, producing enough blood to fill a container - physically impossible for unleavened bread.
The Host survived being thrown into fire without burning - defying all natural laws of combustion.
The Host arose from boiling water and hovered in mid-air - demonstrating supernatural power over gravity.
The Host transformed visibly into the form of a crucifix showing Christ's crucifixion - witnessed by Jonathas and others present.
Historical documentation in Archbishop Rupp's 'History of the Church of Paris' provides ecclesiastical verification.
King Philip the Fair's official confiscation and transformation of Jonathas's house into a chapel was recorded in a bill of sale from 1291, providing civil documentation of the event.
The miracle was officially recognized by Church authorities and the civil government within one year of its occurrence.

witnessTestimonies.name: Jonathas
witnessTestimonies.testimony: I hated the Catholic Faith and did not believe Christ was present in the Eucharist. I stabbed the Host to prove it was merely bread, but it bled like living flesh. I threw it in the fire, but it rose from the flames. I cast it into boiling water, but it arose and transformed into a crucifix before my eyes. I can no longer deny - Christ is truly present in the Holy Eucharist.

witnessTestimonies.name: Parishioner of Saint-Jean-en-Grève
witnessTestimonies.role: Woman who received the Host from Jonathas
witnessTestimonies.testimony: When Jonathas brought me the Host and told me what had happened - how it bled, survived fire and boiling water, and became a crucifix - I was filled with both horror at the sacrilege and awe at the miracle. I immediately took the Blessed Sacrament to our parish priest, where it belongs.

witnessTestimonies.name: Parish Priest of Saint-Jean-en-Grève
witnessTestimonies.role: Priest who received the miraculous Host
witnessTestimonies.testimony: When this woman brought me the Host and recounted the extraordinary events, I immediately reported it to the ecclesiastical authorities. This miracle powerfully demonstrates the Real Presence of Our Lord Jesus Christ in the Eucharist and shows His patience and mercy even toward those who gravely offend Him.

witnessTestimonies.name: Archbishop Simon Matifas of Busay
witnessTestimonies.testimony: After thorough investigation, I confirm the authenticity of this Eucharistic miracle. The Host survived fire, boiling water, and manifested as a crucifix - all witnessed by multiple persons. This is undeniably a divine intervention to strengthen faith in the Most Holy Eucharist.

witnessTestimonies.name: King Philip IV (Philip the Fair)
witnessTestimonies.testimony: Upon learning of this remarkable miracle, I order that the house of Jonathas be confiscated and transformed into a chapel where the Holy Eucharist will be honored and venerated. This house of sacrilege shall become a 'House of Miracles' - a place of prayer and reparation for offenses against the Blessed Sacrament.

timeline.event: Jonathas obtains a consecrated Host with the intention of desecrating it to disprove the Real Presence.
Jonathas stabs the Host with a knife. It begins to bleed profusely, filling the container.
Jonathas throws the Host into fire. Instead of burning, it rises from the flames and hovers in mid-air.
Jonathas throws the Host into boiling water. It rises from the water, hovers in the air, and transforms into a visible crucifix.
Jonathas gives the Host to a parishioner of Saint-Jean-en-Grève, who brings it to her parish priest.
The parish priest reports the miracle to ecclesiastical authorities. Bishop Simon Matifas of Busay begins investigation.
King Philip the Fair officially confiscates Jonathas's house and orders it transformed into a chapel called 'The House of Miracles.' This is recorded in an official bill of sale.
The miraculous Host is enshrined in a reliquary and venerated in the small church of Saint-Jean-en-Grève, becoming a site of pilgrimage.
During the anti-religious violence of the French Revolution, the precious relic is lost without a trace, along with countless other sacred objects destroyed by revolutionaries.
Though the physical relic was lost, the miracle is documented in historical Church records and continues to be remembered as a powerful testimony to the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.

churchInfo.name: Original site: Church of Saint-Jean-en-Grève (destroyed during French Revolution)
churchInfo.address: Historical site in the Marais district of Paris, France
churchInfo.visitingHours: The original church no longer exists, but the miracle is commemorated in Paris churches and documented in Church historical archives

name: Augsburg, 1194
fullDescription:
In the year 1194, in the city of Augsburg, Germany, a woman who was particularly devoted to the Most Holy Sacrament received Holy Communion during Mass. However, after receiving the Host on her tongue, she committed a grave act of sacrilege. Without being noticed by anyone, she secretly removed the consecrated Host from her mouth, wrapped it in a handkerchief, and took it home with her.

At her home, the woman placed the stolen Eucharistic Host in a container made of wax and hid it inside a cupboard in her house. For five long years, she kept this terrible secret, saying nothing to anyone about what she had done. The Host remained hidden in the wax container in her cupboard, unknown to the world.

By 1199, five years after the theft, the woman's conscience began to torment her unbearably. The weight of what she had done - stealing the Body of Christ - filled her with such remorse that she could no longer keep silent. On May 11, 1199, she went to confess her sin to Father Berthold, the superior of the Convent of the Heilig Kreuz (Holy Cross).

Father Berthold, shocked by her confession, instructed the woman to bring the Host back immediately. When she returned with the wax container, the priest carefully opened it, not knowing what condition the Host would be in after five years. What he discovered left him in awe - the Host had miraculously transformed into bleeding Flesh. The Host appeared divided into two parts, still connected together by thin threads of bleeding, living flesh.

Father Berthold immediately went to Bishop Udalskalk of Augsburg to report the miracle. The Bishop ordered that the miraculous Host be transferred with great solemnity to the cathedral. Accompanied by clergy and a vast crowd of faithful, the Bleeding Host was carried in solemn procession through the streets of Augsburg and enshrined in a crystal monstrance (ostensorium) in the cathedral for public worship and adoration.

The miracle did not end there. From Easter Sunday until the Feast of St. John the Baptist (June 24), the Host continued to manifest miraculous phenomena visible to all who came to venerate it. Witnesses reported that the Host began to grow and swell before their eyes, a supernatural phenomenon that continued for months.

Beyond the transformation of the Host itself, other extraordinary miracles occurred in connection with this Eucharistic wonder: The faithful witnessed the Host transform to show the Baby Jesus dressed in radiant white garments, His face shining with divine light and His forehead encircled with a crown of gold. On another occasion, a crucifix in the church began to bleed in the presence of the miraculous Host. Jesus Himself appeared, blessing the assembly of worshipers who had gathered in adoration.

The miraculous Host has been preserved under glass in the Church of the Holy Cross in Augsburg for over 800 years, remaining in perfect condition without any form of artificial preservation - a continuing witness to the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.
historicalContext: This miracle occurred in medieval Germany during a period when Eucharistic devotion was growing but also when sacrilege against the Blessed Sacrament was not uncommon. The fact that God chose to manifest this miracle after the Host had been stolen and hidden for five years demonstrates His patience and mercy, as well as His desire to draw souls back to repentance and faith. The extensive and varied miraculous phenomena - the bleeding flesh, the growth of the Host, visions of the Christ Child and the crucified Savior - made this one of the most documented and celebrated Eucharistic miracles of the Middle Ages.
scientificEvidence: The Host transformed into visible flesh after being hidden in wax for five years - a transformation that occurred in a sealed container away from any external influence.
The flesh appeared as two parts connected by thin threads of bleeding tissue, visible to multiple witnesses including priests and the bishop.
The Host continued to grow and swell visibly over a period of months (from Easter to the Feast of St. John the Baptist), witnessed by countless pilgrims.
The miraculous Host has been preserved in perfect condition under glass for over 800 years without any artificial preservation methods.
Multiple supernatural phenomena were documented: visions of the Christ Child, the bleeding crucifix, and appearances of Jesus blessing the assembly.
The miracle was officially investigated and authenticated by Bishop Udalskalk of Augsburg.
The Host remains intact and visible to this day in the Church of the Holy Cross in Augsburg.

witnessTestimonies.name: The Woman of Augsburg
witnessTestimonies.testimony: I am filled with terrible remorse for what I did. Five years ago, I received Holy Communion but secretly took the Host home instead of consuming it. I hid it in a wax container in my cupboard. My guilt has tormented me day and night until I could bear it no longer. When Father Berthold opened the container, we found that the Host had become bleeding flesh. I see now the gravity of my sin against Our Lord.

witnessTestimonies.name: Father Berthold
witnessTestimonies.role: Superior of the Convent of the Holy Cross
witnessTestimonies.testimony: When this woman came to confession and revealed her terrible secret, I instructed her to bring the Host immediately. Upon opening the wax container after five years, I witnessed a miracle - the Host had transformed into bleeding flesh, divided into two parts connected by thin threads of living tissue. I immediately reported this to our Bishop, and we processed with the miraculous Host to the cathedral.

witnessTestimonies.name: Bishop Udalskalk
witnessTestimonies.testimony: After examining the miraculous Host and verifying the testimony of Father Berthold and the woman, I ordered that this precious relic be transferred to our cathedral with all solemnity. It has been placed in a crystal ostensorium for public veneration. The faithful continue to witness extraordinary phenomena - the Host grows before our eyes, and visions of Our Lord appear to the worshipers.

witnessTestimonies.name: Witnesses in the Cathedral
witnessTestimonies.role: Faithful who venerated the miraculous Host
witnessTestimonies.testimony: We have seen wonders beyond description. The Host grows and swells before our eyes, as if it were alive. Some of us have seen the Baby Jesus dressed in white with a radiant face and a golden crown on His forehead. Others have witnessed the crucifix in the church bleeding in the presence of the miraculous Host. Jesus Himself has appeared, giving His blessing to those gathered in prayer. This is truly the Body of Christ.

timeline.event: A woman in Augsburg secretly removes a consecrated Host from her mouth after Communion, takes it home, and hides it in a wax container.
The Host remains hidden in the woman's cupboard for five years. She tells no one of her sacrilege.
Overcome with remorse, the woman confesses her sin to Father Berthold, Superior of the Convent of the Holy Cross.
Father Berthold opens the wax container and discovers the Host has transformed into bleeding flesh - two parts connected by thin threads of living tissue.
Father Berthold reports the miracle to Bishop Udalskalk. The Bishop orders a solemn procession to transfer the miraculous Host to the cathedral.
The miraculous Host is enshrined in a crystal monstrance in Augsburg Cathedral for public worship and adoration.

timeline.date: Easter Sunday 1199 - Feast of St. John the Baptist (June 24)
timeline.event: The Host continues to manifest miracles, visibly growing and swelling before witnesses for months.
Multiple extraordinary phenomena occur: visions of the Christ Child in white with a golden crown, the bleeding crucifix, and appearances of Jesus blessing the assembly.
The miraculous Host is preserved under glass in the Church of the Holy Cross, remaining in perfect condition for over 800 years.
The miraculous Host can still be venerated in the Church of the Holy Cross in Augsburg, continuing to bear witness to the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist.

churchInfo.name: Church of the Holy Cross (Heilig-Kreuz-Kirche)

name: Bolsena, 1264
fullDescription:
In 1263, a German priest named Peter of Prague stopped at Bolsena while on a pilgrimage to Rome. Though he was a pious priest, he found it difficult to believe that Christ was actually present in the consecrated Host. He was troubled by the apathy of many faithful, clerical immorality and laxity, and a lack of reverence at Mass.

While celebrating Holy Mass above the tomb of St. Christina in the church named for this martyr, he had barely spoken the words of Consecration when blood started to seep from the consecrated Host and trickle over his hands onto the altar and the corporal (linen cloth). The priest was immediately confused. At first he attempted to hide the blood, but then he interrupted the Mass and asked to be taken to the neighboring city of Orvieto, where Pope Urban IV was residing.

Pope Urban IV listened to the priest's account and absolved him. He then sent emissaries for an immediate investigation. When all facts were ascertained, he ordered the Bishop to bring the Host and the blood-stained linen cloth to Orvieto. With archbishops, cardinals and other Church dignitaries in attendance, the Pope met the procession and, amid great pomp, had the relics placed in the cathedral.

One year after the miracle, in August 1264, Pope Urban IV instituted the feast of Corpus Christi. He commissioned St. Thomas Aquinas to compose the liturgical texts for the feast, including hymns still sung today such as 'Pange Lingua' and 'Tantum Ergo.'
historicalContext: The Miracle of Bolsena occurred during a turbulent period in Church history marked by widespread doubt about the Real Presence and lack of reverence for the Eucharist. This miracle directly led to Pope Urban IV instituting the universal Feast of Corpus Christi in 1264, one of the most important celebrations in the Catholic liturgical calendar. The event took place just one year after the miracle, showing the Church's immediate recognition of its significance.
scientificEvidence: The blood-stained corporal has been preserved for over 750 years and remains on display in the Cathedral of Orvieto.
The linen cloth shows clear bloodstains in the pattern of a face, radiating from the center where the Host rested.
The relics have been examined by Church authorities throughout the centuries and maintained their integrity without any form of artificial preservation.

witnessTestimonies.name: Father Peter of Prague
witnessTestimonies.role: German Priest on pilgrimage to Rome
witnessTestimonies.testimony: I doubted the Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist. But when I spoke the words of Consecration, blood began flowing from the Host onto my hands and the altar. I could no longer deny what my eyes witnessed - Christ is truly present in the Blessed Sacrament.

witnessTestimonies.name: Pope Urban IV
witnessTestimonies.testimony: After hearing the priest's account and confirming the miracle through investigation, I ordered the relics brought to Orvieto. This miracle is a sign from Heaven calling us to deeper reverence for the Most Holy Eucharist. I hereby institute the Feast of Corpus Christi for the universal Church.

witnessTestimonies.name: St. Thomas Aquinas
witnessTestimonies.testimony: At the Pope's request, I have composed the liturgical office for the new feast of Corpus Christi. The Eucharist is the source and summit of our faith - in it, Christ gives Himself entirely to us under the appearance of bread and wine.

timeline.event: Father Peter of Prague celebrates Mass in Bolsena and witnesses blood flowing from the consecrated Host onto the corporal.
The priest travels to Orvieto to report the miracle to Pope Urban IV.
Pope Urban IV orders an investigation and has the bloodstained corporal brought to Orvieto in solemn procession.
Pope Urban IV issues the papal bull 'Transiturus de hoc mundo' instituting the Feast of Corpus Christi for the universal Church.
St. Thomas Aquinas composes the liturgical office for Corpus Christi, including 'Pange Lingua,' 'Tantum Ergo,' and other hymns still used today.
Construction begins on the Cathedral of Orvieto to house the sacred relics.
The blood-stained corporal is preserved and displayed in the Chapel of the Corporal in Orvieto Cathedral. An annual procession commemorates the miracle.
